title: What-if Playbook: Energy & KPI Simulation Guidance
overview: This playbook provides practical assumptions and interpretation tips for common what-if questions (LED retrofit, occupancy reduction, reduced operating hours) and how outdoor weather context can influence HVAC-driven electricity consumption.

scenarios.name: Switch to LED lighting
typical_impacts: Lighting energy can drop by 50-70% depending on baseline technology and hours of operation.
A secondary benefit may appear in cooling seasons due to reduced internal heat gains.
kpi_notes: Total kWh tends to decrease; energy per person decreases if occupancy is constant.
If occupancy changes at the same time, per-person KPIs should be interpreted together with fixed loads.
recommended_measures: LED conversion in high-use areas first
Occupancy sensors for intermittently used rooms
risk_and_checks: Measure before/after with sub-metering where possible

scenarios.name: 20% fewer people / occupancy reduction
typical_impacts: Energy rarely drops 1:1 with occupancy because a meaningful portion of loads are fixed (baseline HVAC, standby, IT infrastructure).
If spaces are consolidated (closing floors/rooms), fixed-load reductions can become significant.
kpi_notes: Energy per person can increase if fixed loads remain unchanged while occupancy drops.
To realize savings, align schedules, ventilation rates, and open-area footprint with real occupancy.

scenarios.name: Shorter operating hours
typical_impacts: Schedule-dependent loads (lighting, HVAC, part of plug loads) typically scale with operating hours.
A base load remains (server rooms, safety systems, standby devices).
kpi_notes: Total kWh decreases; energy per person depends on whether occupancy also changes.
The benefit is larger when outdoor-indoor temperature difference is large (HVAC-driven periods).
recommended_measures: HVAC setback temperatures during unoccupied hours
Cleaning/security schedules aligned with reduced hours

weather_context.key_idea: When the indoor setpoint differs significantly from outdoor temperature, HVAC load rises. This can increase both total electricity and the incremental impact of scheduling measures.
interpretation_tips: Large ΔT (indoor-outdoor) suggests HVAC-heavy operation; consider setpoint optimization and scheduling as high-leverage levers.
Small ΔT suggests HVAC is less dominant; lighting and plug loads may explain a larger share of consumption.
